snippet.textDisplay: I'm a mental health provider/prescriber and have no problem with PCPs starting antidepressants. I agree, that in certain geographic areas (by the way NOT in Dr. Mike's area) there is poor access to mental health care so the PCP is sometimes the only way that a patient can get help. However, based on my experience and on actual scientific evidence (see STAR-D trial) I disagree with Dr. Mike's statement that most patients who are prescribed an antidepressant by their PCP do well and, so, do not need to be referred to a mental health specialist. Scientifically speaking, only 1/3 of patients who are prescribed an antidepressant do very well on it alone. This fact would indicate that 2/3 of the PCPs patients - not a few as Dr. Mike believes - would need to be referred to a mental health specialist for appropriate care.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a mental health provider/prescriber and have no problem with PCPs starting antidepressants. I agree, that in certain geographic areas (by the way NOT in Dr. Mike's area) there is poor access to mental health care so the PCP is sometimes the only way that a patient can get help. snippet.textDisplay:
Doctor Mike
As a former family medicine doctor, and now a neurosurgeon I can completly agree with all you said in this video. Many patient problems should be treated dominantly by family medicine doctor. The statement from singer was incorrect and potentially harmful to patients and medical community. You as a family doctor have the highest responsibility for your patient because you have holistic approach to patient and get to know your patients best since spending time with them.
The equivalent of that statment in neurosurgery would be: "when someone has back pain refer to see neurosurgeon". Neurosurgeon should be last resort when all else fails and I cant agree more that hospital specialists expect family medicine doctors to treat their patients first and then refer them to other specialists if needed.
I love how you educate and share medicine in the world 😁

snippet.textDisplay: I admire you idealism, but unfortunately many medical professionals are either not educated or willing to think outside of the box if a patient with complex symptoms marches in. I have seen hundreds of doctors in 7 different countries in my 34 years on this earth and it was only thanks to a few rare gems that the rest of them did not manage to kill me. You belong to a new generation of open minded self-critical young professionals without a God complex, but even you and your peers are unwilling to speak out publicly against the harm many doctors do out of fear it may reflect badly on the profession as a whole or harm your own careers. Maybe we have to wait yet another generation, but until then many patients will suffer and die unnecessarily.

snippet.textDisplay: As a therapist (who does not prescribe), I totally agree with what Dr. Mike is saying. If you’re struggling with anxiety, depression, or another mental health concern and decide that medication makes sense for you, there is no reason why you shouldn’t start that process with your PCP. It can be extremely difficult for patients to find psychiatrists that are both affordable/in-network and available. It’s not uncommon for psychiatrists in the community to have 3 month long waitlists! This is especially difficult for patients living in underserved or rural communities. Unless you need treatment for more complex concerns or severe mental illness, managing meds with your PCP makes perfect sense!Also, some people might only need therapy, some people might only need medication, and some people might need both. These are all valid treatment options! Work with your provider to figure out what makes most sense for you.

Some of us know what we're talking about. I have been a Mental Health Provider until I became differently abled and couldn't anymore.

I am VERY involved in National Non-profit Mental Health Organization and am well informed and stay up-to-date on all things Mental Health and Neurology.

Stefani Germanotta knows what she's talking about too.

As a doctor, please be more careful with the messages you are sending over such a large platform here and please become more educated about the importance of mental health as a specialty and why it is imperative that it be treated as such in the socioeconomic climate and dire circumstances today's society finds itself in regarding Mental Health. It's not a simple fix. Never has been, never will be.
Thank you for your time.

snippet.textDisplay:
PCP's do NOT specialize in psychopharmacology and there are SO many different dxs and entirely too many different meds and far too many being used off label for a PCP to stay up to date to effectively treat and successfully navigate the multitudes of different MH dxs that require meds AND therapeutic intervention on any level. That is NOT their speciality, that is WHY there are Psychiatric specialists, Social Workers, and Therapists.
Also, many of the older PCP's in the medical community still prescribe older meds, SNRI's or SSRI's like Nortriptyline, Prozac and Zoloft, for example, which have so many more serious and long term side effects than newer, more multifaceted or refined meds. I've seen PCP's that still have copies of old DSM's hanging around their office, which it's fine for reference if you're looking back to old notes or how a patient was diagnosed and with what criteria years ago, but have the new DSM-V sitting there and clearly haven't even cracked it open to see how diagnoses have changed over the years - and oh how they've changed!
Also, PCP's don't regularly administer PHQ-9's or score for GAD, or do Kessler screenings, conduct AUDIT, PC-PTSD, SSRS, DAST, LEC, or CAGE assessments.
Proper dx'ing, therapy, and the right medication or combination of meds are invaluable to a person who needs it and if a patient is brave enough to ask for help, you should be humble enough to refer them to the proper treatment.
If a patient's problems are not temporary or situational, then PCP's should ALWAYS refer patients to mental health clinicians for further evaluation and/or therapy if there are serious and persistent Mental Health issues that meet criteria for any MH diagnosis. Any corresponding medications should be prescribed and monitored by a PSYCHIATRIST, a Dr of Psychiatry who is familiar with Psychiatric meds, their side effects, the appropriate meds for specific diagnoses, and can treat for servere reactions such as dysphoria, suicidal thoughts or ideations as side effects, for example. PCP's are NOT fully equipped for this and many times, if a patient brings up SI/HI, a PCP's first inclination as a mandated reporter is to call mobile crisis for an eval or require a patient MHA, where a therapist or PSYCHIATRIC Dr will be able to evaluate in the spot, make a determination, and have a much better understanding of whether this is a symptom of a MH d/o or an adverse reaction to a medication.
Dr. Mike,
I hate to say this, but it seems you are a Dr to the stars now. You made it, good for you. But now you serves people with deep pockets - rich people with money and extra resources and disposable income that have the privilege of trying expensive alternative, osteopathic medicine, having fulfilling, meaningful appointments with time to spare. Your patients have the luxury to be picky about who they choose as their doctors and get to build good rapport with you. And I'd bet money that your patients are either private pay or have private insurance.
Your office is probably not in an inner city, you most likely don't serve marginalized communities like mine or people on government insurance like myself that have to call 50 doctors offices to try to find a primary care physician that is even accepting new patients and if they are, do they speak my language and do they accept Medicaid or Medicare? And THAT'S where the system starts to break down for MOST of the people in our country - we're just trying to get even one foot in the door.
You're right about one thing you said - the Mental Health System is even harder to access. But it's up to our PCP's to ADVOCATE for us! Call over referrals if need be, find out the community resources and put together a packet of them and have copies printed to provide to us at your office, call and check in or schedule follow up visits to check in on our mood and actually call us back if we call and say we need help,let us know about Health Home Care Management Services provided by Medicaid Managed Care Organizations, tell us about resources like NAMI and P4SP, find out and tell us about any local drop-in centers where they have Mental Health Providers on site. Do Not to try to play Psychiatrist to us. That's just plain unethical and dangerous and it is inadequate care.
In my case, and in so many others who can barely find a PCP to accept them as a new patient, let alone get an appointment, forget building rapport with them. And sometimes they are just ASSIGNED by Medicaid and people don't even know that they have a PCP listed on their insurance policy! Insane!
Then when a person puts their last thread of hope and energy into doing the work to sign up for insurance and make those calls and obtain that PCP - because let's say they have diabetes and Schizoaffective d/o - they try to get an appointment and they're told they can't get one for 5 weeks. That's what MOST of the general population either working poor or dealing with some sort of disability and on gov't insurance. Most folks with Mental Health dx's out here in the real world, not the YouTube world, have Mcaid or Mcare or huge Spend downs or essential plans with huge deductibles.
So, you see, no rapport built, and the next time that person goes, they'll most likely see a nurse practitioner, a nurse, or a different doctor.
I remember what I was like to be wealthy and have private insurance when I was still able to work. I went to quiet Dr offices of my choosing with ceiling to floor cascade waterfalls, cushy, clean couches, a quiet room to relax, and coffee and tea stations. Then my brain got sick. No, really, my actual brain - I have a neurological disorder, and then Mental Health dx's followed - and I had to go on SSD at 28 years old and get government insurance and find a new doctor because the one I'd had for 10 years that I had "rapport" with didn't accept my new 'second-class-citizen' insurance. In an instant,that rapport meant nothing any I was left to fend for myself. No recommendations of new physicians from my once beloved Doc no resources to follow up with, no good luck. Just don't forget to pay your last copay on the way out before your 'good' insurance ends.

10 years later and it's not just the same, it's so much worse. The underserved populations and marginalized communities end up at Health Care Centers that are a revolving door of new doctors, nurses, and support staff monthly, usually in not so great neighborhoods in beatup, old, sterile looking buildings to keep overhead costs down because they're only get reimbursed for services at Medicaid or Medicare rates and that barely keeps the lights on.

Dr Mike - You just don't seem to get it. There is a Mental Health CRISIS. Ignorance on behalf of PCP's is partly to blame for misdiagnosis, improper courses of treatment or negligence in regards to follow-up. For example, many patients aren't educated about the importance of med compliance, especially life-or-death implications of the proper use of benzodiazepines often prescribed like candy by PCP's for anxiety, for example - because that's not something that PCP's think of - that's something that PSYCHIATRISTS and MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS think of.

Lady Gaga is from NYC. She grew up in a neighborhood next to the Burroughs and witnessed first-hand lead poisoned peers, gentrification, redlining, poverty, homelessness on every corner and in every nook, she's seen people from her own childhood and neighborhoods struggle with these realities while struggling with Mental Health too. And she's struggled with mental health herself for years. And she's using her voice to help others advocate for themselves. And she's being open and honest about the bad and the ugly and she's right - people should seek Mental Health Service from Mental Health Professionals - a PSYCHIATRIST being one of those.

Dr Mike, you've been an open book on here, this YouTube platform you have, and I thank you for that. snippet.textOriginal:
PCP's do NOT specialize in psychopharmacology and there are SO many different dxs and entirely too many different meds and far too many being used off label for a PCP to stay up to date to effectively treat and successfully navigate the multitudes of different MH dxs that require meds AND therapeutic intervention on any level. That is NOT their speciality, that is WHY there are Psychiatric specialists, Social Workers, and Therapists. 
Also, many of the older PCP's in the medical community still prescribe older meds, SNRI's or SSRI's like Nortriptyline, Prozac and Zoloft, for example, which have so many more serious and long term side effects than newer, more multifaceted or refined meds. I've seen PCP's that still have copies of old DSM's hanging around their office, which it's fine for reference if you're looking back to old notes or how a patient was diagnosed and with what criteria years ago, but have the new DSM-V sitting there and clearly haven't even cracked it open to see how diagnoses have changed over the years - and oh how they've changed!
Also, PCP's don't regularly administer PHQ-9's or score for GAD, or do Kessler screenings, conduct AUDIT, PC-PTSD, SSRS, DAST, LEC, or CAGE assessments.
Proper dx'ing, therapy, and the right medication or combination of meds are invaluable to a person who needs it and if a patient is brave enough to ask for help, you should be humble enough to refer them to the proper treatment.
If a patient's problems are not temporary or situational, then PCP's should ALWAYS refer patients to mental health clinicians for further evaluation and/or therapy if there are serious and persistent Mental Health issues that meet criteria for any MH diagnosis. Any corresponding medications should be prescribed and monitored by a PSYCHIATRIST, a Dr of Psychiatry who is familiar with Psychiatric meds, their side effects, the appropriate meds for specific diagnoses, and can treat for servere reactions such as dysphoria, suicidal thoughts or ideations as side effects, for example. PCP's are NOT fully equipped for this and many times, if a patient brings up SI/HI, a PCP's first inclination as a mandated reporter is to call mobile crisis for an eval or require a patient MHA, where a therapist or PSYCHIATRIC Dr will be able to evaluate in the spot, make a determination, and have a much better understanding of whether this is a symptom of a MH d/o or an adverse reaction to a medication. 
Dr. Mike,
I hate to say this, but it seems you are a Dr to the stars now. You made it, good for you. But now you serves people with deep pockets - rich people with money and extra resources and disposable income that have the privilege of trying expensive alternative, osteopathic medicine, having fulfilling, meaningful appointments with time to spare. Your patients have the luxury to be picky about who they choose as their doctors and get to build good rapport with you. And I'd bet money that your patients are either private pay or have private insurance.
Your office is probably not in an inner city, you most likely don't serve marginalized communities like mine or people on government insurance like myself that have to call 50 doctors offices to try to find a primary care physician that is even accepting new patients and if they are, do they speak my language and do they accept Medicaid or Medicare? And THAT'S where the system starts to break down for MOST of the people in our country - we're just trying to get even one foot in the door.
You're right about one thing you said - the Mental Health System is even harder to access. But it's up to our PCP's to ADVOCATE for us! Call over referrals if need be, find out the community resources and put together a packet of them and have copies printed to provide to us at your office, call and check in or schedule follow up visits to check in on our mood and actually call us back if we call and say we need help,let us know about Health Home Care Management Services provided by Medicaid Managed Care Organizations, tell us about resources like NAMI and P4SP, find out and tell us about any local drop-in centers where they have Mental Health Providers on site. Do Not to try to play Psychiatrist to us. That's just plain unethical and dangerous and it is inadequate care.
In my case, and in so many others who can barely find a PCP to accept them as a new patient, let alone get an appointment, forget building rapport with them. And sometimes they are just ASSIGNED by Medicaid and people don't even know that they have a PCP listed on their insurance policy! Insane! 
Then when a person puts their last thread of hope and energy into doing the work to sign up for insurance and make those calls and obtain that PCP - because let's say they have diabetes and Schizoaffective d/o - they try to get an appointment and they're told they can't get one for 5 weeks. That's what MOST of the general population either working poor or dealing with some sort of disability and on gov't insurance. Most folks with Mental Health dx's out here in the real world, not the YouTube world, have Mcaid or Mcare or huge Spend downs or essential plans with huge deductibles. 
So, you see, no rapport built, and the next time that person goes, they'll most likely see a nurse practitioner, a nurse, or a different doctor.
I remember what I was like to be wealthy and have private insurance when I was still able to work. I went to quiet Dr offices of my choosing with ceiling to floor cascade waterfalls, cushy, clean couches, a quiet room to relax, and coffee and tea stations. Then my brain got sick. No, really, my actual brain - I have a neurological disorder, and then Mental Health dx's followed - and I had to go on SSD at 28 years old and get government insurance and find a new doctor because the one I'd had for 10 years that I had "rapport" with didn't accept my new 'second-class-citizen' insurance. In an instant,that rapport meant nothing any I was left to fend for myself. No recommendations of new physicians from my once beloved Doc no resources to follow up with, no good luck. Just don't forget to pay your last copay on the way out before your 'good' insurance ends.

10 years later and it's not just the same, it's so much worse. The underserved populations and marginalized communities end up at Health Care Centers that are a revolving door of new doctors, nurses, and support staff monthly, usually in not so great neighborhoods in beatup, old, sterile looking buildings to keep overhead costs down because they're only get reimbursed for services at Medicaid or Medicare rates and that barely keeps the lights on.

Dr Mike - You just don't seem to get it. There is a Mental Health CRISIS. Ignorance on behalf of PCP's is partly to blame for misdiagnosis, improper courses of treatment or negligence in regards to follow-up. For example, many patients aren't educated about the importance of med compliance, especially life-or-death implications of the proper use of benzodiazepines often prescribed like candy by PCP's for anxiety, for example - because that's not something that PCP's think of - that's something that PSYCHIATRISTS and MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS think of.

Lady Gaga is from NYC. She grew up in a neighborhood next to the Burroughs and witnessed first-hand lead poisoned peers, gentrification, redlining, poverty, homelessness on every corner and in every nook, she's seen people from her own childhood and neighborhoods struggle with these realities while struggling with Mental Health too. And she's struggled with mental health herself for years. And she's using her voice to help others advocate for themselves. And she's being open and honest about the bad and the ugly and she's right - people should seek Mental Health Service from Mental Health Professionals - a PSYCHIATRIST being one of those.

Dr Mike, you've been an open book on here, this YouTube platform you have, and I thank you for that. But please don't minimize the fact that once settle in the states, you've also led a pretty privileged life being a male of white European descent. And you still are. Look at your comments. This is a serious discussion and people are talking about your smile and your shirt bring too tight and how good looking they think you are. Yes, you have a lot of subscribers just because you're a young, good looking, male doctor. And you're making a LOT of money from that alone. Pri.Vil.Lege.
You're just not getting it. She's not a hollywood 'figurehead' as many of your followers insinuated and now believe due to your careless response to her incredibly brave and true interview. And unfortunately, this unnecessary and misleading response that you've posted makes you sound just like the people you urge others not to listen to - OUT OF TOUCH.

snippet.textDisplay:
I read recently that in the UK only 46% of trainee doctors felt adequately trained on mental health issues and as our first point of contact this not good enough.

I agree with what Lady Gaga said because I have experience of the struggle of trying to talk to a GP about mental health issues and being offered antidepressants as the first option.

I understand that psychotherapies such as CBT, DBT are at times found to be just as effective as antidepressants. I also understand that studies show that antidepressants and psychotherapy work best when prescribed together. The fact that I and many people around me are offered antidepressants prior to being offered any other type of support is not acceptable especially considering the side effects of these medications. Compared to the side effects of attending a therapy session, which are none. Why should we not see a specialist who can offer both psychotherapy and antidepressants before accepting pills.

Lady Gaga discussed having DBT which is a therapy most commonly used for borderline personality disorder which in my opinion qualifies as a complex condition and which requires attention of a specialist rather than a general family doctor who I believe aren't sufficiently trained in psychiatry or psychology.

Too often GPs throw out antidepressants without taking time to talk to patients about what taking antidepressants really means. You are clearly from the higher class and probably work in a "nicer" practice and that's why you're experience with patients is different from that of the GPs people like me see. The time and resources pressure for people who are less well off and for the GPs that see them leads to these issues and effects a majority of us.

We need to find a resolve where people like us are offered better treatment, time and support.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have seen so many people prescribed medications that they cannot get off of (turning them into addicts), and that end up killing themselves anyway. I spent much of my career working in the pharmaceutical industry and the second half in law enforcement, and I can tell you just how bad it is. But I fear I don’t have to - too many of us already know first hand.

Drug companies have made their way into medical school curriculums as well. Dr. Michael Gregor has several fantastic videos on this topic.

A drug, if it DOES NOT have the potential pitfall of being highly addictive, may help get you through a really rough patch. But they should be used as sparingly as one can, and, if at all possible, the eventual goal should be mental stability without drug use. Anxiety and depression quite often are signals telling us that something must change within our behavior or lifestyle. It isn’t ALL about the pills folks! They CAN be helpful, but they can also be VERY harmful.
